description: From earlier gamel, from Middle English *gamlen, *gamelen, variant of Middle English gamenen, from Old English gæmnian, gamnian, gamenian (“to joke; play”), related to Old English gamen (“joy; mirth; pleasure; entertainment; pastime; sport; game”), equivalent to game +‎ -le. Compare Old Danish gammel, Middle High German gamel (“pleasure; fun”). More at game.

examples: I had a gamble on the horses last weekend.

entries.meaning: A significant risk, undertaken with a potential gain.

examples: The sailors had taken many gambles with the sea and always won.

verbs.description: gamble (third-person singular simple present gambles, present participle gambling, simple past and past participle gambled)

entries.meaning: To take a risk, with the potential of a positive outcome.
To play risky games, especially casino games, for monetary gain.
examples: Mark won half a million dollars gambling on horses.
He gambled his reputation on the outcome.

entries.meaning: To interact with equipment at a casino
